newsitem.title: JAPAN: U.S. consultancy to review Japan nuclear company.
newsitem.headline: U.S. consultancy to review Japan nuclear company.

text.p: U.S. firm Andersen Consulting has been asked to evaluate operations and management at Japan's troubled state-run nuclear power company, an official of the Science and Technology Agency said on Thursday.
The request was made by the Japanese government agency, which oversees the operations of the Power Reactor and Nuclear Fuel Development Corporation (PNC).
"It's Anderson (that we've asked to make a study) and we are about to sign a contract," the official said.
He added that the two parties hoped to reach a conclusion and make an announcement by the end of this week or early next.
Andersen's findings will be part of a larger study of potential PNC reforms underway by a special government panel, the official said.
"The panel itself hopes to reach some kind of a decision by the summer," he added.
An Andersen spokeswoman said that the deal was still being considered by the Japanese government.
"It is a fact that we did submit a proposal, but we haven't heard anything at this point," she said.
Andersen Consulting is a multibillion dollar global management and technology consultancy that works with clients from a wide range of industries.
A PNC spokesman said that the company had received an unofficial notice from the Science and Technology Agency about the consultancy work.
"We have been told that a company, which we believe is a consulting firm, has been hired to make a (study of PNC) as part of the investigation being undertaken by the agency," the spokesman said.
"Of course we will be cooperating with the effort, which will be rather like giving the company a health check," he said.
A growing list of accidents and cover-ups has placed PNC under intense public scrutiny in recent weeks.
Government officials said on Wednesday they were considering the permanent closure of PNC's Monju prototype fast breeder nuclear reactor on the Sea of Japan coast.
The 280,000 kilowatt reactor was closed last December after an accident involving the leakage of an estimated two to three tonnes of liquid sodium from a cooling system.

In March, a PNC-run nuclear fuel reprocessing plant in Tokaimura on the Pacific coast was the scene of Japan's worst-ever nuclear accident when an explosion exposed 37 workers to low levels of radiation.
Later it was revealed that the chief investigator of Japan's top nuclear agency deliberately destroyed photographs of the accident.
